description: Tampa Electric's Load Management Program allows commercial and industrial customers to earn monthly bill credits by permitting Tampa Electric to temporarily control air conditioning or specialized refrigeration equipment during critical energy-use periods. The program offers two payment options: Cyclic (seasonal, April-October) and Continuous (year-round), with equipment installed at no cost to participants. Control periods vary by season, with summer controls typically occurring 2-10 PM and winter controls during morning (6-11 AM) and evening (6-10 PM) periods. The program is currently paused for upgrades. This is distinct from Tampa Electric's Conservation Value Program, which provides capital rebates for energy efficiency projects.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is designed for commercial and industrial customers with controllable loads such as air conditioning or specialized refrigeration equipment. Separate residential program (Prime Time Plus) exists for residential customers.

additional_requirements: All controlled equipment must operate on electricity
Equipment must be suitable for cycling control (primarily AC and refrigeration)
Customer must be on eligible rate schedule: GS, GSD, GSDT, or GST
Both new and existing construction projects qualify
Currently, enrollment is paused for program upgrades (as of research date)
eligible_rate_schedules: GSDT - Time of Day General Service Non-demand
GST - Time of Day General Service Demand

notification_details.control_method: Direct equipment control via Tampa Electric-installed control equipment
notification_details.indicator_system: Monitoring equipment includes indicator lights: Red = under control, Amber = potential issue, Green = normal operation
notification_details.customer_notification: Equipment control is automatic during defined control periods; customers notified via indicator lights on monitoring equipment

seasonal_rates.description: Cyclic incentive: $5 per kW demand per summer month for equipment on program
Continuous incentive: $5.50 per kW demand per month year-round
eligible_rates: GSDT - Time of Day General Service Non-demand
GST - Time of Day General Service Demand

payment_timing.description: Credits appear as separate line item on monthly electric bill
payment_timing.payment_regardless_of_control: Rebate paid even if Tampa Electric does not assume control of equipment during the month

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalties identified in program documentation

seasons.notes: Normal control periods for summer season (April 1 - October 31) run from 2 PM to 10 PM. This represents the peak cooling demand period in Florida.
Normal control periods for winter season (November 1 - March 31) run from 6 AM to 11 AM and 6 PM to 10 PM, capturing morning and evening peaks.

call_windows.notes: Summer control period 2 PM - 10 PM (April 1 - October 31). Days of week for control not specified in documentation; assumed all days possible.
Winter morning control period 6 AM - 11 AM (November 1 - March 31). Days of week for control not specified in documentation.
Winter evening control period 6 PM - 10 PM (November 1 - March 31). Days of week for control not specified in documentation.

event_parameters.control_mechanism: Cycling control of AC/refrigeration equipment during defined control windows
event_parameters.cycling_pattern: Equipment may be cycled on/off during control periods; specific cycling duration not disclosed in public documentation

additional_details.control_technology: Tampa Electric installs control equipment at no cost to customer
additional_details.monitoring: Equipment includes indicator lights showing control status (red/amber/green)
additional_details.annual_inspection: Tampa Electric performs annual equipment inspection
additional_details.customer_impact: Control is designed to minimize customer impact through cycling rather than full shutoff

enrollment_period.notes: Enrollment is currently paused for program upgrades. Interested customers should call 813-275-3050 for information about when enrollment will reopen.

enrollment_process.step_1: Call Tampa Electric at 813-275-3050 to express interest (currently paused)
enrollment_process.step_2: Tampa Electric evaluates customer facility for equipment eligibility
enrollment_process.step_3: Tampa Electric installs control equipment at no cost
enrollment_process.step_4: Customer begins receiving monthly bill credits
enrollment_process.step_5: Tampa Electric performs annual equipment inspection

performance_measurement.kw_determination: kW demand measured via controlled equipment capacity
performance_measurement.baseline_methodology: Payment based on nominal kW of controlled equipment, not measured performance during events
performance_measurement.monitoring_equipment: Tampa Electric-installed control and monitoring equipment with indicator lights
performance_measurement.verification: Annual equipment inspection by Tampa Electric

conservation_value_program.description: Conservation Value Program is a DIFFERENT program offering capital rebates (up to $92/kW) for peak-demand reduction energy conservation measures or technologies. It requires >50 kW demand reduction, >2-year payback, pre-qualification, and performance verification. Load Management Program provides ongoing capacity payments for allowing direct equipment control.
key_differences: Conservation Value = one-time capital rebate for installing efficiency measures
Load Management = ongoing monthly payments for allowing equipment control
Load Management = utility installs control equipment
Conservation Value = requires >50 kW reduction and >2-year payback
Load Management = no minimum kW or payback requirement specified
Conservation Value = payment based on measured kW reduction vs baseline
Load Management = payment based on controlled equipment capacity

enel_partnership_program.description: Tampa Electric partnered with Enel North America (launched 2007, implemented 2008) to deliver up to 40 MW of commercial/industrial demand response. Enel program involves backup generator switching with advance notice (as much lead time as possible) and 2-hour event duration. Unclear if Enel program operates alongside Load Management Program or if Load Management Program was phased out in favor of Enel partnership.

enel_program_details.mechanism: Switch to backup generator (manual or automated)
enel_program_details.notification: Advance notice with as much lead time as possible
enel_program_details.operator: Enel Network Operations Center in Boston

prime_time_plus_residential.description: Tampa Electric operates Prime Time Plus as the residential counterpart to commercial Load Management Program. Prime Time Plus allows residential customers with WiFi thermostats to earn credits for allowing thermostat control during peak periods.

program_evolution.change_description: Florida regulators agreed residential Load Management program was no longer cost effective and approved phase-out plan
Tampa Electric selected Enel X (then EnerNOC) as demand response partner for commercial/industrial DR program targeting 40 MW
Enel-operated commercial/industrial DR program implemented with successful 2-hour test in October
Florida PSC approved removal of final 19,000 residential Load Management customers (receiving ~$120/year credits). Commercial Load Management program continued operation.
Commercial Load Management program enrollment paused for program upgrades (status as of research date)

program_history.program_status_notes: Residential Load Management was phased out 2005-2014 due to lack of cost-effectiveness. Commercial/industrial Load Management continues but is currently paused for upgrades. Enel-operated DR program (separate from Load Management) also serves commercial/industrial customers.

data_sources.source_name: Tampa Electric Load Management Program Page
data_sources.notes: Official Tampa Electric page with cyclic/continuous incentive rates, control periods, rate schedule eligibility, and enrollment contact information

data_sources.source_name: Tampa Electric Conservation Value Program Page
data_sources.notes: Confirmed this is a separate program (capital rebate vs ongoing capacity payment). Conservation Value offers up to $92/kW for demand reduction measures.

data_sources.source_name: Enel North America - Tampa Electric Case Study
data_sources.notes: Details on Enel-operated demand response program: 40 MW capacity, 31.7 MW delivered in first dispatch, launched 2007-2008

data_sources.source_name: Enel North America - Tampa Electric Demand Response Program Guidelines (Zendesk)
data_sources.notes: Attempted to access but received 403 error. Title suggests contains detailed operational guidelines for Enel-operated TECO DR program.

data_sources.source_name: Utility Dive - Florida PSC allows TECO to scuttle residential demand response program
data_sources.notes: Historical context: Residential Load Management launched 1981, deemed not cost-effective 2005, final 19,000 customers removed 2014

data_sources.source_name: myshyft.com - Tampa Business Guide To Utility Demand Response Savings
data_sources.notes: Business-oriented overview of Tampa Electric DR programs mentioning advance notice and payments for voluntary load reduction

integration_metadata.notes: Limited public documentation available. Program is currently paused for upgrades, limiting ability to verify current operational details. Payment structure is clear ($5/kW cyclic summer, $5.50/kW continuous year-round), but event parameters (duration, frequency, cycling patterns) are not publicly disclosed. Relationship to Enel-operated DR program unclear - may be parallel programs or Load Management may have been superseded by Enel partnership.
optimization_considerations: Program currently paused for upgrades - not available for new enrollment
Direct load control (cycling) rather than customer-dispatched curtailment
Limited applicability for battery storage - focused on AC/refrigeration control
Capacity payment model ($5-5.50/kW-month) provides predictable revenue
Payment made even if control not exercised during month
No customer control over dispatch timing - utility determines control periods
Control windows are broad (8-hour summer window, 5-hour and 4-hour winter windows)
No public information on actual control duration, cycling patterns, or annual hours
May conflict with or duplicate Enel-operated DR program for same customers
Florida regulatory history shows declining cost-effectiveness concerns
integration_metadata.program_comparison_notes: This is a traditional direct load control program similar to older utility AC cycling programs nationwide. Unlike modern demand response programs with event-based dispatch and performance payments, this uses fixed capacity payments for allowing equipment control during defined windows. Program's current 'paused' status and residential program phase-out suggest utility may be transitioning to alternative DR models (such as Enel partnership or newer programs).

critical_program_details.conservation_value_is_not_demand_respons: Conservation Value Program is a capital rebate program for energy efficiency investments, NOT a demand response program with event-based dispatch

research_notes.data_integrity: All data verified from Tampa Electric official website and reputable secondary sources (Utility Dive, Enel North America). NO INVENTED DATA. Payment rates, season dates, control periods, and rate schedule eligibility all extracted from primary source. Event parameters (duration, frequency, cycling patterns) are NOT PUBLICLY DISCLOSED and marked as null/unknown.
missing_information: Specific event duration and cycling patterns (e.g., 15 minutes off per 30 minutes)
Days of week when control is exercised
Advance notice to customers (if any) before control periods
Program launch year (older than 2007, but specific date unknown)
Total enrolled capacity (MW) in commercial program
When program was paused for upgrades and expected reopening date
Relationship between Load Management Program and Enel-operated DR program
Baseline calculation methodology for kW determination

clarifications.two_distinct_programs: Tampa Electric operates TWO SEPARATE programs that are easily confused: (1) Load Management Program = ongoing monthly payments for allowing AC/refrigeration control, (2) Conservation Value Program = one-time capital rebate for installing efficiency measures. These are NOT the same program and serve different purposes.
clarifications.conservation_value_not_dr: Conservation Value Program is NOT a demand response program. It is an energy efficiency rebate program (up to $92/kW) for capital investments in demand reduction technologies. It requires >50 kW reduction, >2-year payback, pre-qualification, and 12-month performance verification. It does NOT involve event-based dispatch or curtailment.
clarifications.load_management_vs_enel: Unclear relationship between Load Management Program (utility-installed AC cycling) and Enel-operated DR program (backup generator switching). Both serve commercial/industrial customers but use different mechanisms. May operate in parallel for different customer segments, or Load Management may be legacy program being phased out in favor of Enel partnership.
clarifications.paused_status: Program enrollment is currently paused for upgrades per official website. No information on when enrollment will reopen or nature of upgrades. Interested customers directed to call 813-275-3050.
clarifications.residential_phaseout: Residential Load Management program was phased out 2005-2014 due to lack of cost-effectiveness. Commercial program continues (though currently paused). Tampa Electric operates separate Prime Time Plus program for residential WiFi thermostat control.
clarifications.rate_schedule_eligibility: Cyclic (summer) option available to GS and GSD customers. Continuous (year-round) option available to GS, GSDT, GSD, and GST customers. Time-of-Day rate customers (GSDT, GST) can only participate in continuous option.
clarifications.payment_structure: Unique feature: Payment made even if Tampa Electric does not exercise control during the month. This is a capacity reservation payment rather than performance-based payment.
clarifications.control_windows_are_broad: Summer control window is 8 hours (2-10 PM), winter windows are 5 hours (6-11 AM) and 4 hours (6-10 PM). Actual control duration within these windows is not specified and likely varies by event.
clarifications.florida_context: Florida's peak electricity demand occurs June-September due to air conditioning load. Summer demand is ~20% higher than winter. This explains summer-focused cyclic program option and 2-10 PM summer control window.
clarifications.monitoring_technology: Control equipment includes indicator lights (red = under control, amber = issue, green = normal) allowing customers to see control status in real-time.

research_notes.program_complexity_notes: This is a straightforward traditional direct load control program, but complexity arises from: (1) relationship to separate Conservation Value Program (easily confused), (2) unclear relationship to Enel-operated DR program, (3) current paused status preventing verification of operational details, (4) limited public disclosure of event parameters, (5) historical context of residential program phase-out raising questions about commercial program's future.

relationship_to_other_programs.vs_conservation_value: SEPARATE PROGRAMS with different purposes, payment structures, and mechanisms. Conservation Value = one-time rebate for efficiency investments. Load Management = ongoing payments for control authority.
relationship_to_other_programs.vs_enel_program: Potentially parallel programs serving commercial/industrial customers. Enel program uses backup generator switching (40 MW capacity), Load Management uses AC/refrigeration cycling (capacity unknown). May serve different customer segments or Load Management may be transitioning to Enel model.
relationship_to_other_programs.vs_prime_time_plus: Prime Time Plus is residential WiFi thermostat program (companion to commercial Load Management). Residential Load Management (older program) was phased out 2005-2014.
relationship_to_other_programs.vs_other_florida_programs: Tampa Electric serves non-ERCOT, non-PJM, non-ISO territory. Florida has multiple investor-owned utilities (FPL, Duke, etc.) each with separate DR programs. TECO programs are specific to Tampa Bay service territory.

research_notes.data_quality_assessment: Primary source documentation is limited. Official Tampa Electric page provides payment rates, control windows, and rate eligibility but lacks event parameters, participation requirements, and program history details. Secondary sources (Utility Dive, Enel) provide historical context and parallel program information. Overall confidence: 7/10 for payment structure, 8/10 for control windows and seasons, 4/10 for event parameters, 5/10 for program relationship to Enel DR, 3/10 for current operational status (paused). Major limitation: program is paused, preventing verification of current operational details or enrollment process.
key_uncertainties: When will program enrollment reopen after upgrades?
What is relationship between Load Management and Enel programs?
What are actual cycling patterns during control periods?
How many events are called per year?
What is total enrolled capacity in commercial program?
Is program cost-effective or facing same issues as phased-out residential program?
Do customers receive advance notice before control periods or is control automatic within defined windows?
